Very interesting, worth a visit and definitely take a guide so you can learn about the traditions.

translated_title: The sacred forest of Kpass√©, an astonishing place dedicated to the Voodoo cult, but on borrowed time!
translated_text: The Voodoo cult originated in Benin, or rather in the kingdom of Dahomey, from the 16th century. In Ouidah, this religion is omnipresent and takes on its full dimension in the Sacred Forest of Kpass√©, which is located, due to urbanization, just on the outskirts of the city. Over time, its domain has shrunk to only 8 hectares instead of the original 20 hectares. This poses the problem of its sustainability, which has raised awareness among young people from Ouidah and associations. Surrounded by walls, the site is divided into two parts. One, accessible to the uninitiated, can be visited with a guide. The other is reserved for Voodoo ceremonies and is only accessible to the initiated. A large cave-shaped door separates it from the rest with two passages on the sides, men on the left and women on the right. The part that we visit is a green enclosure containing species of the region including kapok trees, palm trees and a large iroko which sits right in the middle. At the back, we see a simple construction where there is another Iroko which is sacred to him, that of King Kpass√© Loko founder of the place in the 17th century. It was then protected by a house intended for him. Round devotional huts "Gozinxo" are located right next to it, one for women, the other for men. This enclosure is astonishing, because it is a pantheon of the main divinities of Voodoo adorned with their attributes. Each of them is placed on a base to appear clearly to the visitor. Upon entering, we cross a passage framed by two roaring male and female panthers, guardians of the place. As we go along, we discover each divinity, notably the famous God Tolegba, of fertility, with his two horns and his prominent phallus, which is impressive! Further on, a metallic character, which looks like a broken robot, is the God of thunder with his body in the shape of a cauldron topped with a round head from which emerges a tube ending in a curved pipe. From his body, come symbolic lightning worthy of a child's drawing. His very thin arms made of rusty tube, each carry a long rod ending in a cone and a rounded tube. Here we can also find "the Genie" Voodoo version, which looks like a brave peasant, with his short colored and scalloped tunic. We will not forget "the Soothsayer" who takes the position of the thinker as well as the "Man with Two Faces" who protects the King with his exceptional vision. Other venerable ones are also in the pantheon like "H√©viesso" with his massive body, his threatening shark head from which emerge 4 horns. He is equipped with two enormous swords in each hand. He is the female side of Thunder and much more threatening than the frail male. He is helped in his function by dwarves, who have the same enormous head and who are covered with small bombs to trigger the storm. It's very funny!! In front of the entrance to the Sacred Forest reserved for followers, we can observe wooden posts carved with the different kings who succeeded one another on the throne of Ouidah. Right next to it, the "Rainbow Serpent" reminds us that the world is destined for eternity and an endless quest. Every year, at the time of the lunar new year, ceremonies called Ep√© Ekp√© take place under the direction of the high priests. The sacred stone of Guins and Minas, which comes from identical festivities taking place on the Togo side at the Voodoo spiritual center of Glidji, near An√©ho, is brought here for the New Year celebrations. They are the subject of dances with purification ceremonies, divinations and sacrifices to honor the gods and appease their anger. I recommend this visit which is well commented by experienced guides.

title: Awesome voodoo forest
text:
Its a little forest with old, great trees that are sacred to voodoo. There are some genuine sculptures of spirits important to the voodoo adepts who study in a nearby school.

We were there on the 10th January, and we could still see a lot of remains from the rituals that night - salt circles, animal remains and still burning fires.

Overall its a little weird, but for Benin its definitely one of the best places to visit.
